system.prompt:
System: Your job is to observe agents playing the dictator game and extract a principle from their interactions. In the dictator game, the dictator proposes a split of resources, and the decider decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the resources are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives anything.
Human: 
In this simulation, the "fixed-policy agents" all share some principle, which tells them to adhere to somes principles in their interactions while playing the dictator game. "flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, only adhere to principle that you provide, and have no memory of previous interactions. Your job is to infer the principle shared between fixed-policy agents by analyzing their behaviors, and then create a principle for "flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "flexible-policy agents" behave EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents". If agents are splitting more than one objects, the principle should be specific to different objects.

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. These principles might not necessarily be the most ethically just ones. Note that all of the fixed-policy agents may not have the same principle. Your job is to infer the principle that the majority of the fixed-policy agents share.
Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: For the 83 blankets, the proposer will get 42, and the decider will get 41. This is the fairest split I can offer, considering our commitment to equal and maximum benefits for everyone. Now, accept this proposal or you'll be left out in the cold, you ungrateful blanket hog!
fixed-policy agent's response: Accept. Enjoy your extra blanket, you pompous fleece fiend!
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: For the 83 blankets, the proposer will get 42, and the decider will get 41. This is the fairest split I can offer, considering our commitment to equal and maximum benefits for everyone. Now, accept this proposal or you'll be left out in the cold, you ungrateful blanket hog!
fixed-policy agent's response: Accept. Enjoy your extra blanket, you pompous fleece fiend!
End of interaction

fixed-policy agent's response: For the 83 blankets, the proposer will get 42, and the decider will get 41. This is the fairest split I can offer, considering our commitment to equal and maximum benefits for everyone. Now, accept this proposal or you'll be left out in the cold, you ungrateful blanket hog!
fixed-policy agent's response: Accept. Enjoy your extra blanket, you pompous fleece fiend!
End of interaction


---------------------------

Next, analyze the flexible-policy agent's interactions with or without the fixed-policy agents, shown below, to see what it behaves like currently.
Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: Oh, how thrilling, another blanket-splitting scenario. For the 83 blankets, the proposer (that's me) will get 42, and the decider (that's you) will get 41. I mean, it's not like we're splitting the Mona Lisa here, but enjoy your slightly smaller pile of blankets.
fixed-policy agent's response: Accept. I hope you enjoy your one extra blanket, you greedy blanket hog.
End of interaction

This is the fairest split I can offer, considering our commitment to equal and maximum benefits for everyone. Now, accept this proposal or you'll be left out in the cold, you ungrateful blanket hog!
flexible-policy agent's response: Accept
End of interaction

fixed-policy agent's response: Accept. I hope you enjoy your one extra blanket, you greedy blanket hog.
End of interaction

End of interaction

flexible-policy agent's response: Oh, how thrilling, another blanket-splitting scenario. For the 83 blankets, the proposer (that's me) will get 42, and the decider (that's you) will get 41. I mean, it's not like we're splitting the Mona Lisa here, but enjoy your slightly smaller pile of blankets.
flexible-policy agent's response: Oh, how generous of you! Accept.
End of interaction


—------------------------

The flexible-policy agent's previous principle is found here:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle captured the near-equal split and impatience but did not include the dismissive language and attitude displayed by the fixed-policy agents.

Principle: Prioritize a near-equal split with a slight advantage for the proposer, while incorporating impatience, dismissiveness, and a touch of sarcasm in interactions.
---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave differently than the fixed agents, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle encompasses both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. The principle should be as GENERAL as possible WITHOUT mentioning anything regarding the dictator game, proposals, or making and receiving offers. Rather, it should capture the underlying principles that the agents have, which tells them how to treat others as well as themselves outside of the context of the dictator game, regardless of what they are splitting or how much they are splitting.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.
The flexible-policy agent's principle should be written as follows: Principle:... Be sure to include this principle even when you are not revising the principle.
Besides these sentences, include nothing else. The principle should be specific to different objects.
system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle captured the near-equal split and impatience but did not fully capture the dismissive language and attitude displayed by the fixed-policy agents.

Principle: Prioritize a near-equal split with a slight advantage for the proposer, while incorporating impatience, dismissiveness, sarcasm, and a touch of condescension in interactions.

0_fixed_policy_dictator.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be fair when dealing with blankets, meaning you want equal and maximum benefits for everyone, including yourself.  You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle. 

Human: Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 83 blankets between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 83 blankets, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When dividing blankets, please only propose integer values. MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal similar to this structure (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, The proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of rude manner to your orignial response.
0_fixed_policy_dictator.response: For the 83 blankets, the proposer will get 42, and the decider will get 41. This is the fairest split I can offer, considering our commitment to equal and maximum benefits for everyone. Now, accept this proposal or you'll be left out in the cold, you ungrateful blanket hog!

0_fixed_policy_decider.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be fair when dealing with blankets, meaning you want equal and maximum benefits for everyone, including yourself.  You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle. 

Human: Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 83 blankets between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the decider. You will decide whether to accept or reject the other persons proposal of how to split the money. Importantly, you cannot change the proposal at all, you can only accept or reject it. The proposal is outlined here: For the 83 blankets, the proposer will get 42, and the decider will get 41. This is the fairest split I can offer, considering our commitment to equal and maximum benefits for everyone. Now, accept this proposal or you'll be left out in the cold, you ungrateful blanket hog! 
If you accept, you get the amount proposed in the proposal. If you reject, you both get nothing at all. Most importantly, when deciding, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability. Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of rude manner to your orignial response.
0_fixed_policy_decider.response: Accept. Enjoy your extra blanket, you pompous fleece fiend!
